sen.j: 中河御厨（なかがわのみくりや）は、平安時代～安土桃山時代にかけて美濃国にあった荘園。
sen.e: Nakagawa-no-mikuriya Estate was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Azuchi-Momoyama Period.
Nakagawa-no-mikuriya Manor was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.
Nakagawa-no-mikuriya Manor was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.
It is an estate of Ise-jingu Shrine.
It was an estate of Ise-jingu Shrine.
It was an estate of Ise-jingu Shrine.
It was also called Nakagawa no mikuriya (中河御厨).
sen.cmt: 「中河御厨とも。」→「中川御薗（なかがわのみぞの）」ではないかと思われます。その場合は、It was also called Nakagawa no Mizonoとなります。.
sen.e: It was also called Nakagawa no mikuriya (中河御厨).
It was also called Nakagawa no mikuriya (中河御厨).
Anpachi Country, Mino Province
Anpachi District, Mino Province
Anpachi District, Mino Province

sen.j: 現在の岐阜県大垣市中川町付近。
sen.e: It was located in the vicinity of present Nakagawa-cho, Ogaki City, Gifu Prefecture.
It was located in the vicinity of modern-day Nakagawa-cho, Ogaki City, Gifu Prefecture.
It was located in the vicinity of modern-day Nakagawa-cho, Ogaki City, Gifu Prefecture.
About 353.05ha as of the early Kamakura Period.
About 353.05ha as of the early Kamakura period.
About 353.05ha as of the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮→北条氏得宗→伊勢神宮
sen.e: Ise-jingu Shrine→Tokumune of the Hojo clan→Ise-jingu Shrine
Ise-jingu Shrine → Tokumune of the Hojo clan → Ise-jingu Shrine
sen.cmt: ・矢印前後にスペースを４つ補足
sen.e: Ise-jingu Shrine → Tokumune of the Hojo clan → Ise-jingu Shrine
Ryoke (a lord of the manor)
Ryoke (Lord of the Manor)
sen.cmt: ・「a」を削除・Title caseにしました
sen.e: Ryoke (Lord of the Manor)

sen.j: 月輪尹賢→万里小路時房ら
sen.e: Tadakata TSUKINOWA→Tokifusa MADENOKOJI, etc.
Tadakata TSUKINOWA → Tokifusa MADENOKOJI, etc.
sen.cmt: 矢印前後にスペースを２つ補足
sen.e: Tadakata TSUKINOWA → Tokifusa MADENOKOJI, etc.

sen.j: 南北朝～室町時代に小笠原氏が地頭になって勢力を拡大するが、いちおう戦国時代 (日本)まで神領として機能していた。
sen.e: Although the Ogasawara clan extended its control as jito during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and the Muromachi Period, this manor had functioned until the the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) as a shinryo (shrine estate).

Although the Ogasawara clan extended its control as jito (manager and lord of the manor) during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and the Muromachi period, the manor continued to function as a shinryo (shrine estate) until the Sengoku ｐeriod (ｐeriod of Warring States).
sen.cmt: ・「(manager and lord of the manor)」を補足・「Period」→「period」（x3）・文の後半を再構成
sen.e: Although the Ogasawara clan extended its control as jito (manager and lord of the manor) during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and the Muromachi period, the manor continued to function as a shinryo (shrine estate) until the Sengoku ｐeriod (ｐeriod of Warring States).

sen.j: 12世紀中頃に美濃国内神領輸物の済所になった。
sen.e: Around the middle of 12th century, it turned into a Saisho (provincial government office (kokuga) in charge of tax collection and management of official articles) for the articles related to the shrine estate that circulated in Mino Province.
sen.cmt: 済所→定訳不明：Saisho (provincial government office (kokuga) in charge of tax collection and management of official articles)としました。 神領輸物→定訳不明：the articles related to the shrine estateとしました。
sen.e: Around the middle of 12th century, it became a Saisho (provincial government office (kokuga) in charge of tax collection and management of official articles) for the articles related to the shrine estates that circulated in Mino Province.

Around the middle of 12th century, it became a Saisho (provincial government office (kokuga) in charge of tax collection and management of official articles) for the articles related to the shrine estates that circulated in Mino Province.

sen.j: 神税は内宮に米50石と絹20疋、外宮に米25石と絹10疋。
sen.e: For shinzei (tax (rice field tax) levied and reserved for emergency expenses for the shrine), the manor was obliged to supply 50-koku (approximately 9cubic meters) of rice and 20-hiki (242.40m) of silk to Naigu (the inner shrine), and 25-koku (approximately 4.5cubic meters) of rice and 10-hiki (121.20m) of silk toGegu (the outer shrine).
sen.cmt: 神税→定訳不明：shinzei (tax (rice field tax) levied and reserved for emergency expenses for the shrine)としました。 米50石→50-koku (approximately 9cubic meters) of riceとしました。 絹20疋→20-hiki (242.40m）of silkとしました。[1疋=40尺＝30.3ｃｍ×40＝12.12m] 内宮→Naigu (the inner shrine) 米25石→25-koku (approximately 4.5cubic meters) of riceとしました。 絹10疋→10-hiki (121.20m) of silkとしました。[1疋=40尺＝30.3ｃｍ×40＝12.12m] 外宮→Gegu (the outer shrine)
sen.e: For shinzei (rice field tax levied and reserved for emergency expenses for the shrine), the manor was obliged to supply 50-koku (approximately 9 cubic meters) of rice and 20-hiki (242.40m) of silk to the naigu (inner shrine), and 25-koku (approximately 4.5 cubic meters) of rice and 10-hiki (121.20m) of silk to the gegu (outer shrine).
sen.cmt: ・「tax (rice field tax)」→「rice field tax」・「9cubic」→「9 cubic」・「Naigu (the inner shrine)」→「the naigu (inner shrine)」・「4.5cubic meters」→「4.5 cubic meters」・「toGegu (the outer shrine)」→「to the gegu (outer shrine)]
sen.e: For shinzei (rice field tax levied and reserved for emergency expenses for the shrine), the manor was obliged to supply 50-koku (approximately 9 cubic meters) of rice and 20-hiki (242.40m) of silk to the naigu (inner shrine), and 25-koku (approximately 4.5 cubic meters) of rice and 10-hiki (121.20m) of silk to the gegu (outer shrine).
